h3. Summary
There is an excessive delay in loading the editor for a Confluence page that has several Jira Issue Macros (JIM) that are using the 'Total Issue Count' option in the 'Display Options'. This appears to be linked to Jira servers/clusters that have a million issues (or more).

h3. Environment
Confluence 7.4.3.
Jira 8.5.8 (maybe other versions of JIRA as well)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Jira 8.5.8 and Confluence 7.4.3 in test environment. I used PSQL db for the test.
# Populate the application data in JIRA to have 500k to 1 million issues. Confluence can be at default settings.
# Setup an application link between the two servers.
# In Confluence, create a new test page with 15 JIM macros each using JQL to filter the table and make sure that in the 'Display Options' in the macro, the 'Total Issue Count' option is selected. The filter should have a high amount of issues included (500k to 1 million) among several of the macros.  Save the page.
# Notice it reaches out to JIRA to pull total issues for each macro.
# While on the test page, click the EDIT button (top right).

h3. Expected Results
The editor should load in a reasonably quick time, or at least inline with how long it takes to query and retrieve the total issue values from Jira.

h3. Actual Results
The editor takes 3x-5x the time it should to fully load before being available to edit the page.

h3. Notes
- The delay comes from the editor reaching out to JIRA and requesting/loading the total issue counts _after_ the EDIT button has been pressed. This is to include the total issue count for the macros in the editor.
- While viewing a page, there are asynchronous REST calls to get the total issue count for the macros (this is behaving normally) which is several times faster than in edit mode.
- Customers have observed that the delay in v6.15.9 is 50% less than in v7.4.3. for the editor with the same dataset in Jira.

h3.Workaround
- Splitting page into smaller pages will help with page load.
- Starting from versions 7.8.1 and 6.13.18, in the [dark features|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/dark-features-in-confluence-1079350770.html], we would need to add "confluence.extra.jira.edit.ignore.count" to prevent Confluence from making requests to Jira. Due to that change, instead of a real count number, we will see "x" in edit mode.
fields.summary: Can not edit a page with 42 JIRA Issue Macros

Confluence in-place editing (aka in-line editing) does not always work properly when switching between edit and view modes. Sometimes the user cursor is unexpectedly taken to the beginning (or end) of the document when going to edit mode.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a test page filled with several screens of plain text. Optionally create a few headings for reference only

# type 'e' to edit the page
#* Expected: Edit screen will open with the second page of the document visible
# type cmd/control+S to save the page
# Back in view mode, scroll down to view the fifth page of the document (hit page down three more times)
# type 'e' to edit the page
#* Expected: Edit screen will open with the fifth page of the document visible
# type cmd/control+S to save the page
# Keep scrolling around the document and switching between editing and view modes (save the document each time)


h3. Expected Results
Edit screen should open at the same place being viewed by the user every time

h3. Actual Results
Sometimes the editor opens with the cursor in the wrong place (e.g. at the beginning or end of the document). See video below where the problem happens at around 1:10... The 'e' key was pressed with "content 5" visible, but the editor opened the document at "Content 1".
 [^in-place editing not opening page at expected position.mp4] 
 
h3. Notes
There is already a bug open to address in-line editing issues when switching between edit and preview modes at https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-41302. 

At the time of opening, this bug was reported in the following environments:
 - Macbook Pro and Chrome Version 53.0.2785.143 (64-bit) -- customer environment

I could not reproduce the bug with:
 - Macbook Pro and Firefox 49.0.1 build id 20160922113459 -- Atlassian support environment
 
h3.Workaround
No direct workaround. It looks like Firefox browser might be less prone to this problem.

 An 'undefined' page is any page that has been linked to from within Confluence, but that does not yet exist.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-44329].
{panel}
We have dozens of spaces and need ability to programmatically update space permissions. Otherwise it's a really wasteful manual effort.
h3. Workaround

While this is not possible through the REST API, Confluence users and administrators can still use the legacy RPC API to administrate [Space Permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/conf613/assign-space-permissions-964960245.html].
 The following document describes the JSON-RPC API: [Confluence JSON-RPC APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/confluence-json-rpc-apis/].
 The following document highlights all the methods available in the RPC API to manage Space Permissions: [Remote Confluence methods – Permissions|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/remote-confluence-methods/#permissions-1].
 The following link will send you to a mapping about each space permission string and their related permission: [Remote Confluence methods – Space Permissions|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/remote-confluence-methods/#space-permissions].

Below are a few examples of how to use this API to perform Space Permissions operations.
 This is using {{Shell Script}} just as an example, since it can be ported to your preferred coding language.
 In these examples, the [jq library|https://stedolan.github.io/jq/] is used to filter and format the raw output.
h5. Get all permissions associated to a Space
{code:java}
#######
# Attributes to set
#######
ADMIN_USRNAME=<username to perform basic authentication>
ADMIN_USRPWD=<password to perform basic authentication>
CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL=<Confluence Base URL>
SPACE_KEY=<Target Space Key>

####### Run the API method
API_METHOD=getSpacePermissionSets
curl --user $ADMIN_USRNAME:$ADMIN_USRPWD -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Accept: application/json" -X POST -d '{ "jsonrpc" : "2.0", "method" : "'${API_METHOD}'", "params" : ["'${SPACE_KEY}'"], "id": 7 }' ${CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL}/rpc/json-rpc/confluenceservice-v2?os_authType=basic 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.result[]'
{code}
Running example and output excerpt:
 !getSpacePermissionSets-img001.png|thumbnail!
h5. Get users and groups assigned as Space Administrators to a Space
{code:java}
#######
# Attributes to set
#######
ADMIN_USRNAME=<username to perform basic authentication>
ADMIN_USRPWD=<password to perform basic authentication>
CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL=<Confluence Base URL>
SPACE_KEY=<Target Space Key>
PERMISSION_TYPE=<permission type string>

####### Run the API method
API_METHOD=getSpacePermissionSet
curl --user $ADMIN_USRNAME:$ADMIN_USRPWD -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Accept: application/json" -X POST -d '{ "jsonrpc" : "2.0", "method" : "'${API_METHOD}'", "params" : ["'${SPACE_KEY}'", "'${PERMISSION_TYPE}'"], "id": 7 }' ${CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL}/rpc/json-rpc/confluenceservice-v2?os_authType=basic 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.result[]'
{code}
Running example and output excerpt:
 !getSpacePermissionSet-img001.png|thumbnail!
h5. Set Add Page permission to a specific group in a Space
{code:java}
#######
# Attributes to set
#######
ADMIN_USRNAME=<username to perform basic authentication>
ADMIN_USRPWD=<password to perform basic authentication>
CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL=<Confluence Base URL>
SPACE_KEY=<Target Space Key>
GROUP_NAME=<Target Group Name>
PERMISSION_TYPE=EDITSPACE

####### Run the API method
API_METHOD=addPermissionToSpace
curl --user $ADMIN_USRNAME:$ADMIN_USRPWD -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Accept: application/json" -X POST -d '{ "jsonrpc" : "2.0", "method" : "'${API_METHOD}'", "params" : ["'${PERMISSION_TYPE}'", "'${GROUP_NAME}'", "'${SPACE_KEY}'"], "id": 7 }' ${CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL}/rpc/json-rpc/confluenceservice-v2?os_authType=basic 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.'
{code}
Running example and output excerpt:
 !addPermissionToSpace-img001.png|thumbnail!
h5. Set Delete Attachments to a specific user in a Space
{code:java}
#######
# Attributes to set
#######
ADMIN_USRNAME=<username to perform basic authentication>
ADMIN_USRPWD=<password to perform basic authentication>
CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL=<Confluence Base URL>
SPACE_KEY=<Target Space Key>
USER_NAME=<Target Username>
PERMISSION_TYPE=<permission type string>

####### Run the API method
API_METHOD=addPermissionToSpace
curl --user $ADMIN_USRNAME:$ADMIN_USRPWD -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Accept: application/json" -X POST -d '{ "jsonrpc" : "2.0", "method" : "'${API_METHOD}'", "params" : ["'${PERMISSION_TYPE}'", "'${USER_NAME}'", "'${SPACE_KEY}'"], "id": 7 }' ${CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL}/rpc/json-rpc/confluenceservice-v2?os_authType=basic 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.'
{code}
Running example and output excerpt:
 !addPermissionToSpace-img002.png|thumbnail!

h3. Environment
Confluence 5.10.7
Active Directory LDAP

h3. Actual behavior

Confluence does not add the LDAP users inside the local groups when the LDAP is set with the permission, "Read only with local groups" and have the same group name inside the tree.

h3. Steps to replicate

1) Install Confluence 5.10.7
2) Create a Group called Confluence-users in the LDAP
3) Setup Confluence with AD LDAP, read only with local groups and set the default group membership as Confluence-users.
4) Set the internal directory in the first position.
5) Full Sync.
6) Confirm that the LDAP users are inside Confluence and choose one user.
7) Verify that this user is not inside the Confluence-users group.
8) Logout and login as this user.
9) You'll see a not permitted screen, as the user was not present in the Confluence-users group.
10) Login as local administrator confirms that the user is not part of the Confluence-users group.

h3. Expected behavior

Confluence should add the users to the local groups when selected in the LDAP configuration menu.

h3. Workaround

During local testing, when the LDAP is placed on the first position and a new user logins, the user is correctly placed inside the Confluence-users group, so this is the workaround for now.

It seems that the directory order directly activates the bug.
fields.summary: Users are not automatically added to the default group when using LDAP with local groups permission

h3. Summary
Whenever a table is dropped in Confluence, all foreign key constraints must be removed as well prior to the removal of the table itself. However, Confluence's upgrade tasks are very static and will only remove the foreign key constraints that were added by Confluence. Any other FK constraints will remain and won't be deleted.

(i) This bug is discussing the removal of the {{ATTACHMENTS}} table along with non-self-referential FK constraints.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup Confluence 5.6 or any pre-5.7 version whereby {{ATTACHMENTS}} is still being used by Confluence to store attachment details. Make sure it's using an external database.
# Create a new space in this site with some pages and insert attachments into them.
# Access the database and insert a new foreign key constraint into the {{ATTACHMENTS}} table. For example:
 {code}ALTER TABLE ATTACHMENTS ADD CONSTRAINT test FOREIGN KEY (PAGEID) REFERENCES CONTENT (CONTENTID);{code}
# Upgrade that instance to 5.7 or later successfully.
# Start Confluence.
# Try to delete the space created in step #2.

h3. Expected Results
The space can be deleted.

h3. Actual Results
The space can't be deleted due to the FK constraint that was left behind when the {{ATTACHMENTS}} table was removed.

Here are the FK constraints before upgrade:
{code}
CONSTRAINT `FK54475F9017D4A070` FOREIGN KEY (`PREVVER`) REFERENCES `attachments` (`ATTACHMENTID`),
CONSTRAINT `FK54475F908C38FBEA` FOREIGN KEY (`PAGEID`) REFERENCES `content` (`CONTENTID`),
CONSTRAINT `FK_ATTACHMENTS_CREATOR` FOREIGN KEY (`CREATOR`) REFERENCES `user_mapping` (`user_key`),
CONSTRAINT `FK_ATTACHMENTS_LASTMODIFIER` FOREIGN KEY (`LASTMODIFIER`) REFERENCES `user_mapping` (`user_key`),
CONSTRAINT `test` FOREIGN KEY (`PAGEID`) REFERENCES `content` (`CONTENTID`)
{code}

Here are the FK constraints after upgrade:
{code}
CONSTRAINT `FK54475F9017D4A070` FOREIGN KEY (`PREVVER`) REFERENCES `attachments_backup` (`ATTACHMENTID`),
CONSTRAINT `test` FOREIGN KEY (`PAGEID`) REFERENCES `content` (`CONTENTID`)
{code}

h3. Suggestion
The upgrade task should remove all foreign keys that are not self-referential to avoid issues like this.
fields.summary: Non-static upgrade task for removal of foreign key constraints when tables are dropped

h3. Summary

The {{created:}} search field is showing different results while performing a query search. If you add a timestamp date(_yyyymmddThhmmss_), Lucene will return other results with a syntax without the timestamp syntax.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a page in Confluence
 # Use the following query:
 #* I'll use today's date as example
{code:java}
created:[20161009T:00:00:00 TO 20161010T:00:00:00]
{code}
 # The created page will be returned.
 # Use the following filter
{code:java}
created:[20161009 TO 20161010].
{code}
 # The page created "today" won't be displayed, although we just removed the timestamp

h3. Expected Results

Both range queries should return the same results
h3. Actual Results

The simplified query will only display the same results if I add 1 day ahead:
 # Change from
{code:java}
created:[20161009 TO 20161010]
{code}
 # To:
{code:java}
created:[20161009 TO 20161011]
{code}

h3. Notes

There's no explanation about the results or the timestamp syntax at [https://lucene.apache.org/core/2_9_4/queryparsersyntax.html] . It just says that "Sorting is done lexicographically", but doesn't explain why the results are not the same.
h3. Workaround

No workaround.
fields.summary: Lucene Range Search not working properly

h3. Summary

The "..." menu at the top right in the file preview that expands to show the "Edit" option for Microsoft Office documents when running Internet Explorer doesn't show at all.

h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Load up Confluence with  IE.
 # Embed a Word or Excel document in a page via Insert > File and Images.
 # Click on the thumbnail to open that document in the file preview.

h3. Expected results

As well as the download, upload, share, and close icons at the top-right, there should be a "..." dropdown with "Edit" that allows the user to edit the document directly in Microsoft Office or OpenOffice (as per [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ConfCloud/Office+Connector+Prerequisites]). It should look like this (taken from Firefox): 
!edit_options.png|thumbnail!

h3. Actual results

The "..." dropdown is totally missing.

h3. Notes
This is similar to this bug: [CONF-40756|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-40756] which was resolved. In this case, however, it is only occurring in Internet Explorer.

Synchrony generates wrong credentials when connecting to database, if Confluence is configured using a JNDI datasource.

We use a Tomcat JDBC datasource to connect Confluence to our MySQL server. With Confluence 6.0 rc 2 Synchrony uses this datasource (Previous bug) but generated the wrong user name to connect to the MySQL server.

atlassian-synchrony.log displays:
{code:java}
java.sql.SQLException: Access denied for user 'root@sbdevcon1.schb.local'@'sbdevcon1.schb.local' (using password: YES)

{code}
The datasource used by Confluence & configured in server.xml is:
{code:java}
<Resource name="jdbc/confluence" auth="Container" type="javax.sql.DataSource"
 username="root"
 password="XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX"
 driverClassName="com.mysql.jdbc.Driver"
 url="jdbc:mysql://mydbserver.mydomain/confluence?sessionVariables=storage_engine%3DInnoDB&useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=utf8" 
 defaultTransactionIsolation="READ_COMMITTED"
 validationQuery="SELECT 1"
 initialSize="10"
 maxTotal="30"
 maxIdle="10"
 minIdle="0" 
 maxWaitMillis="-1"
 timeBetweenEvictionRunsMillis="30000"
 minEvictableIdleTimeMillis="60000"
 testOnBorrow="true"
 removeAbandonedOnBorrow="false"
 removeAbandonedOnMaintenance="false"
 removeAbandonedTimeout="120"
 logAbandoned="true"
 />

{code}
As you can see, the user name "root" is appended with the Confluence server name. This user is not configured AND cannot be created in MySQL because the username exceeds 16 chars. No workaround is known by now.

Best regards,

Jan-Peter Rusch

h3. Summary

When we try to delete a space which was imported from a Cloud version then the import does not complete and we see a foreign key violation on the table {{usercontent_relation}} in the logs
h3. Environment

Cloud version
Confluence 5.10.x
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Export a space from cloud version
 # Import it to Confluence 5.10.x
 # Delete the imported space

h3. Expected Results

The space should be deleted
h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-confluence.log file and space does not get deleted the progress is stuck at some point:
{noformat}
2016-10-07 21:51:50,457 ERROR [Long running task: Space removal long running task] [atlassian.confluence.event.ConfluenceEventDispatcher] lambda$getRunnable$1 There was an exception thrown trying to dispatch event [com.atlassian.confluence.event.events.space.SpaceWillRemoveEvent[source=com.atlassian.confluence.spaces.DefaultSpaceManager@422da8a5]] from the invoker [com.atlassian.confluence.event.ConfluenceListenerHandlersConfiguration$TimingListenerHandler$1$1@43b5b300]
 -- space: 98307 | url: /spaces/doremovespace.action | traceId: 187467d29377f21f | userName: admin | referer: http://localhost:8090/spaces/removespace.action?key=MIZ | action: doremovespace
java.lang.RuntimeException: Hibernate operation: could not delete: [com.atlassian.confluence.pages.Page#65601]; SQL []; ERROR: update or delete on table "content" violates foreign key constraint "fkecd19ced351d64c3" on table "usercontent_relation"

*Please take a Db backup and throughly test the below workaround before applying it to production instance*

TRUNCATE table USERCONTENT_RELATION;

  {panel}

h4. Summary
Let's say our hierarchy of pages in a page are as such:
 * Parent A (contains ImageA.png and ImageB.png)
 ** Child A (displays ImageA.png that was attached in Parent A)
 ** Child B (displays ImageB.png that was attached in Parent A)

On pages Child A and Child B, the only way to know that ImageA.png and ImageB.png originated from Parent A is to edit the page and hover over the image. At that point, you'd be able to view which space and page the image came from. A sample is shown below:

 !Attachment hover.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Suggestion
The method mentioned above is very troublesome and difficult for users to identify which page actually has the attachment attached to it. Perhaps Confluence can do one of the following:
 * Automatically link the attachment so clicking on it will immediately redirect users to the original page where the attachment was attached to.
 * Provide a macro which can list out the links to pages whose attachments are displayed on the current page.

Any other implementation method that will allow an easier way of knowing which page provides the attachment would be great.

h4. Workaround
This will achieve suggestion #1 above, but has to be manually done.
 # Edit an existing page or create a new page.
 # Insert an attachment from another page into the page from step #1 above.
 # Click on the newly added attachment on the page editor.
 # Click on "Link".
 # Search for the page where the attachment came from.
 # Select the page.
 # Click on "Insert".
 # Save the page.
 # Click on the attachment to test the URL/page redirection.

In our team we wanted to create a subpage on a personal space and share them with others (view and edit the page),
So we gave "view" and "edit" permissions to the page, to the parent page (space home) and only "view" permissions to the personal space itself.

The page info stated that "user X has edit permission". So that was fine. But editing did not work.

The manual (https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/space-permissions-overview-139521.html)states that the "add pages" permission on the space gives the right to edit pages too.
That sounds a bit strange. You need to give a user the permission to add pages (or comments, etc.) just that he will be able to edit a page.


That should probably be changed to "Add/Edit" or divided into two permissions.

Das OpenOLAT 10.5 Benutzerhandbuch hat zahlreiche Kommafehler. Insbesondere nach Relativpronomen (meistens DIE) wird oft keine Komma gesetzt. Grammatikalische Fehler sind in der Regel selten, aber in folgendem Abschnitt sehr häufig (inkl. Kommafehler):

Mit dem Coaching-Tool haben Gruppen- und Kursbetreuer die Möglichkeit, alle Ihnen zugewiesen Benutzer auf einen Blick zu sehen und zu verwalten. Falls Sie eine Gruppe oder einen Kurs betreuen, [KEIN KOMMA] und im Kurs wird durch Bewertungsdaten ein Leistungsnachweis ausgelöst, so wird der Reiter "Coaching" in der oberen Navigation erscheinen. Das Coaching-Werkzeug bietet einen Kursübergreifenden [ADJEKTIV: KLEINSCHREIBUNG] Überblick über den Bewertungsstatus von Lernenden - den betreuten Benutzern.  Kursbesitzer erhalten Zugriff auf die Daten aller ihrem Kurs eingebundenen Benutzer, egal ob als Kurs- oder Gruppenmitglied. Dabei werden alle bewertbaren Kursbausteine berücksichtigt. Bitte beachten Sie, dass Kurse erst dann als bestanden angezeigt werden können, wenn der Kurshauptknoten ebenfalls entsprechend konfiguriert wurde. Zugriff auf betreute Personen gibt es auf drei verschiedene Weisen.

Benutzen Sie das Menü [KOMMA fehlt] um die Lernstatistiken von einzelnen Benutzern, Gruppen oder ganzen Kursen zu sehen. Ein Fortschrittsbalken zeigt an [KOMMA] wie weit ein Benutzer, eine Gruppe oder ein Kurs bereits benötigte Bewertungen erhalten haben. Die Listenansicht kann nach Spalten sortiert werden.

Beim Einstieg in das Coaching-Werkzeug finden Sie alle von Ihnen betreuten OpenOLAT-Benutzer. Diese Tabelle verschafft Ihnen einen Überblick, in wievielen [WIE VIELEN] von Ihnen betreuten Kursen ein Benutzer Mitglied ist, [KEIN KOMMA] und wieviele [WIE VIELEN]  er davon schon bestanden hat. Ein Klick auf den Namen öffnet die Benutzerspezifische [ADJEKTIV: KLEINSCHREIBUNG] Kursübersicht. In dieser Ansicht können Sie auch einfach die Pfeilnavigation nutzen [KOMMA] um zwischen Benutzern zu wechseln.
